åŸæ–‡: PyCoder's Weekly - Issue #480

  • 210707 Zoom.Quiet(å¤§å¦ˆ) ç”¨æ—¶ 42 åˆ†é’Ÿ å®Œæˆå¿«è¯‘
  • 210707 Zoom.Quiet(å¤§å¦ˆ) ç”¨æ—¶ 37 åˆ†é’Ÿ å®Œæˆæ ¼å¼è½¬æŠ„.
  • Python çš„ç±»å‹ç±»
    • NIKITA SOBOLEV
    • â€¢ Shared by Nikita Sobolev

Sometimes you need to change the behavior of a function based on the type of argument passed to it. This is a classic example of polymorphism in programming. In this article, youâ€™ll learn how this is typically done in Python, compare that to polymorphism in other languages, and see how the new classes library can make the whole process easier.

  • Django REST æ¡†æ¶ä¸­/è‡ªå®šä¹‰æƒé™ç±»
    • TESTDRIVEN.IO
    • â€¢ Shared by Å pela Giacomelli
    • (aka GirlLovesToCode)

One of the great things about Django REST Framework (DRF) is how easy it is to be productive with the built-in API views and permission classes. But sometimes you need a bit more control than the built-in objects allow. This article walks you through how to create and use custom permission classes in DRF so that you can have complete control over how permissions work in your REST API.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

è¿™ç§æƒ³ç»•è¿‡æ¡†æ¶çš„å°è¯•, å¤šæ•°éƒ½æ²¡èƒ½åšæŒå¤šä¹…...

  • Monitor Your Python Applicationsâ€™ Performance in Real Time with Datadog APM
    • DATADOG
    • sponsor

Pinpoint hard-to-reproduce problems in your production code without affecting your appâ€™s performance with Datadogâ€™s Continuous Profiler. Locate which functions (or lines of code) consume the most resources, such as CPU and memory and optimize for a better app experience. Try Datadog APM free â†’

  • Python è®¡æ•°å™¨: Pythonic æ–¹å¼è®¡æ•°å¯¹è±¡
    • REAL PYTHON

In this step-by-step tutorial, youâ€™ll learn how to use Pythonâ€™s Counter to count several repeated objects at once. Youâ€™ll also learn how to use Counter objects to enhance other computations that you do in Python.

  • Django Security å‘å¸ƒ: 3.2.5 and 3.1.13
    • DJANGO SOFTWARE FOUNDATION

æ¢è®¨/åç³Ÿ

Discussions

  • ä¸ºæ¯› is a, b = b, a å¹¶ä¸æ€»æ˜¯ç­‰ä»·äº b, a = a, b ?
    • STACK OVERFLOW

In Python you can swap the values of two variables without creating a temporary variable. So, if you have two variables a = 1 and b = 2, you can swap their values using a, b = b, a. Now a has the value 2 and b has the value 1. So shouldnâ€™t b, a = a, b do the same thing? In most cases, it will, but one user on Stack Overflow found an instance where they donâ€™t, and the explanation gets into the nitty-gritty about how assignments are evaluated.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

å› ä¸º...æ‰€ä»¥...

)

æ–‡ç« /æ•™ç¨‹/å—¯å“¼

Articles, Tutorials and Talks

  • ç”¨ SQLAlchemy è´¯é€š Python å’Œ PostgreSQL æšä¸¾
    • BRENDAN LE

An Enumlets you restrict variables to a set of constants. You can use them to map values that would typically be strings to integer constants, which helps reduce human error due to misspellings. SQLAlchemy also supports enums for use with your database layer. This article shows you how to generate an SQLAlchemy enum from a Python Enum instance so that your data can live in a single place and be shared between the Python and database layers of your application.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

åæ­£è¿ DB ç”¨ SQLAlchemy æ²¡é—®é¢˜

)

  • ç”¨ Papermill å‚æ•°åŒ–å’Œè‡ªåŠ¨åŒ– Jupyter Notebook
    • MATT WRIGHT

Jupyter Notebooks are a great way to create reproducible experiments and data analysis, but sometimes you want to alter parameters used in the notebook to see how the results change. One way to do that is with the papermill package. Using papermill, you can execute a notebook with new parameters straight from the command line.

  • ç”¨ Dustin Ingram ä¿æŠ¤æ‚¨çš„ Python è½¯ä»¶ä¾›åº”é“¾
    • REAL PYTHON
    • podcast

How well do you know your software supply chain? When you PIP install a package, what steps can you take to minimize the risk of installing something malicious? This week on the Real Python Podcast, we have Dustin Ingram, a director of the Python Software Foundation (PSF) and a maintainer of the Python Package Index (PyPI).

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

  • å¦‚ä½•åœ¨ Python ä¸­å¤„ç† JWT
    • JESSICA TEMPORAL
    • â€¢ Shared by Robertino

JavaScript Web Tokens (JWTs) are used to store information about web users. They are compact and can be used to authorize users in APIs. In this article and how to create and verify them in Python using the PyJWT package.

  • å®šä¹‰å’Œè°ƒç”¨ Python å‡½å¼
    • REAL PYTHON
    • course

In this course, youâ€™ll learn how to define and call your own Python function. Youâ€™ll also learn about passing data to your function and returning data from your function back to its calling environment.

2021 Python Web Conference è§†é¢‘å‘å¸ƒ

åŸæ–‡: PyCoder's Weekly - Issue #479

  • 210630 Zoom.Quiet(å¤§å¦ˆ) ç”¨æ—¶ 42 åˆ†é’Ÿ å®Œæˆå¿«è¯‘
  • 210630 Zoom.Quiet(å¤§å¦ˆ) ç”¨æ—¶ 37 åˆ†é’Ÿ å®Œæˆæ ¼å¼è½¬æŠ„.
  • Python Redux ä¸­çš„å­ç±»åŒ–
    • HYNEK SCHLAWACK

Have you ever heard someone say that composition is better than inheritance? Itâ€™s an age-old conflict in object-oriented programming thatâ€™s been the impetus for numerous online debates. Author Hynek Schlawack, who describes himself as â€œfirmly in the composition-over-inheritance campâ€ explains in this article how â€œPython is designed in a way that you canâ€™t write idiomatic code without subclassing sometimes.â€

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

ç»„åˆæ€»æ¯”ç»§æ‰¿é¦™? çœ‹åœºæ™¯äº†, å¦‚æœè¦åˆ†åŒ…ç»™å°åº¦å¼Ÿå…„ä»¬, è¿˜æ˜¯ç»§æ‰¿å§...

)

  • Python ä¸­çš„ç›¸å…³åˆ†æåˆæ­¥
    • OLGA BEREZOVSKY
    • â€¢ Shared by Olga Berezovsky

Correlation analysis is a useful part of exploratory data analysis. It can help you identify potential relationships between various features of your data. In this helpful guide, youâ€™ll learn how to do correlation analysis in a pandas DataFrame. Youâ€™ll see how to display a correlation matrix as a heatmap and explore some guidelines for identifying when correlation might imply causation.

  • åè½¬ Python åˆ—è¡¨: è¶…è¶Š .reverse() å’Œ reversed()
    • REAL PYTHON

In this step-by-step tutorial, youâ€™ll learn about Pythonâ€™s tools and techniques to work with lists in reverse order. Youâ€™ll also learn how to reverse your list by hand.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

  • Python 3.9.6, 3.8.11, 3.7.11, and 3.6.14 ç°å·²æ¨å‡º

    • REAL PYTHON

With CPython Internals: Your Guide to the Python 3 Interpreter, youâ€™ll unlock the inner workings of the Python language, learn how to compile the Python interpreter from source code, and cover what youâ€™ll need to know to confidently start contributing to CPython yourself.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

æ¢è®¨/åç³Ÿ

Discussions

  • Tkinterâ€¦ ä¸é”™å‘¢
    • REDDIT

Tkinter. Sometimes it seems like you either love it or hate it. While Tkinter doesnâ€™t check all the boxes for every GUI, it definitely has its use cases. And the fact that it comes built into the Python standard library is a huge plus. This Reddit thread spreads some much-needed love for the library.
